Heteropoly acids (HPAs) of the Keggin type exhibit substantial Brønsted acidity and are commonly utilized as acid catalysts, particularly in acrylic acid synthesis via glycerol oxydehydration. The primary goal of this research is to comprehensively assess the morphological and physicochemical properties of SBA-15 supported HPAs (H4SiW12O40.xH2O, H3PW12O40.xH2O, and H3PMo12O40.xH2O). The synthesized catalysts were characterized via physisorption analysis, XRD, SEM, FT-IR, NH3-TPD, and H2-TPR. Furthermore, the catalyst's catalytic activity in acrylic acid synthesis via single-step liquid phase glycerol oxydehydration was evaluated by correlating its characteristics with glycerol conversion and acrylic acid yields. The PW/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited the best performance, with the highest acrylic acid yield reaching 17.5% at 87.8% glycerol conversion. Given that the partial oxidation of acrolein to acrylic acid necessitates an optimal level of redox properties, the superior performance of PW/SBA-15 was characterized by high acid sites and moderate oxidative capabilities. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Glycerol Acrylic acid Heteropoly acid supported SBA-15 catalysts Oxydehydration reaction Oxidative capability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Glycerol is produced as a by-product of biodiesel production, and the sector's growth has consequently led to an oversupply of glycerol in the market. Acrylic acid plays a vital role in the fine chemical industry due to its wide range of applications across various industrial sectors. The acrylic acid produced undergoes an upgrading process to yield glacial acrylic acid, which is subsequently polymerized into polyacrylic acid, a well-known superabsorbent material mainly used in the personal care industry [1]. Furthermore, the increasing demand for acrylate ester derivatives (i.e., butyl acrylate, ethyl acrylate, and 2-ethylhexyl acrylate) plays a crucial role in driving market growth. These derivatives find extensive applications in various industries, such as textiles, paints, adhesives, and coating materials [2]. The glycerol-to-acrylic acid conversion via oxydehydration is in fact a two-step reaction. Initially, glycerol undergoes dehydration, resulting in the formation of 3-hydroxypropanal, an extremely reactive intermediate that dehydrates readily into acrolein [3]. In the subsequent step, acrolein is oxidized selectively when molecular oxygen is present, leading to acrylic acid production. Either a combined dehydration-oxidation bed system with a functionalized catalyst in each bed [4] or a single reactor with a bi-functional catalyst [5] can be used to carry out the oxydehydration process. In order to optimize the glycerol conversion and enhance the acrylic acid selectivity, researchers have utilized a range of bi-functional catalysts that possess both acidic and oxidative properties such as heteropoly acids, d-block metals, and mixed metal oxides. These catalysts are employed within a single reactor setup, allowing for improved efficiency and performance. Extensive research has been conducted on a diverse range of heterogeneous catalysts, such as vanadyl pyrophosphate catalysts [6–8], unsupported mixed metal oxide catalysts [5,9–16], molecular sieve catalysts [17–21], and supported heteropoly acid catalysts [22–24], with the aim of enhancing acrylic acid synthesis in a single-step glycerol oxydehydration reaction. To date, HPA-based heterogeneous catalysts have garnered significant attention thanks to their remarkable catalytic activity attributed to the Keggin structure, which enables the formation of well-ordered cluster configurations and imparts considerably enhanced Brønsted acidity. They possess strong but widely tuneable acidity which makes them to be able to catalyze many organic reactions. Their acidity stems from the ability to act as proton donors (Brønsted acidity) and electron acceptors (Lewis acidity) due to the presence of metal sites in their molecules. Meanwhile, SBA-15 is a promising support material due to its large pores, high surface area, and thermal stability, which are advantageous for reactions like glycerol oxydehydration to acrylic acid. Hence, introducing HPA into the silica framework can produce a selective catalyst with high catalytic active sites. Several investigations on the application of HPA/SBA-15 catalyst in oxidation [25], dehydration [26], acetalization [27], and carbonylation [28] have been published. Liu et al. [26] studied the catalytic acrolein synthesis via glycerol dehydration and this research group compared the performance of two catalysts: SBA-15 supported HPW and Cs+ modified SBA-15 supported HPW catalysts. They revealed that the 50HPW/Cs-SBA-15 catalyst outperformed the 50HPW/SBA-15 catalyst, achieving as high as 85% acrolein selectivity at complete glycerol conversion. This suggests that Cs+ modification improved HPW dispersion and partially neutralized strong acid sites, enhancing catalytic performance. In 2018, Chen et al. [27] conducted a study on the acetalization of glycerol with formaldehyde, focusing on optimizing the loading of HPA salts (Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40) onto mesoporous silica supports (KIT-6, SBA-15, and SBA-16). Their research aimed to determine the ideal loading and investigate how the pore structure and size of the silica supports influence catalytic activity. They found that a 30 wt% HPA salts loading was the most effective for the catalytic process. However, the variations in the mesoporous silica supports, ranging from 2D SBA-15–3D KIT-6 and SBA-16, had minimal impact on the catalytic performance. In a recent study by Shen et al. [28], they utilized a wet impregnation method to create SBA-15 supported HPA catalysts. Their primary goal was to improve the Brønsted acid sites’ availability in the synthesized catalysts for dimethyl ether (DME) carbonylation into methyl acetate (MA). They supported three types of HPA (HPMo, HSiW, and HPW) on SBA-15 and examined the impact of acid strength. The catalytic reaction was conducted for 1.5 h at 200 °C using 1.0 g of catalyst, and they selected a 25 wt% acid loading due to better dispersion. Their findings indicated that the catalysts with more and stronger acid sites facilitated the formation of methyl acetate. Notably, they observed that HPMo had a tendency to decompose on SBA-15 at a lower temperature, consequently leading to a substantial reduction in the catalyst’s Bronsted acidity, primarily attributed to the creation of more Lewis acid sites. In short, SBA-15-supported HPA represents a promising catalyst with respect to its strong Bronsted acidity, thermally stable, and high surface area. Also, with appropriate oxidation potential, this catalyst can also be used as a redox catalyst, providing bi-functionality. Hence, in this short communication, we illustrate how the interplay between the acid/redox properties and pore characteristics of HPA supported by SBA-15 catalysts plays a crucial role in facilitating the acrylic acid synthesis via single-step glycerol oxydehydration in liquid phase. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of HPA/SBA-15 catalysts The SBA-15 support was synthesized following a reported method [29]. The incorporation of HPAs into SBA-15 was accomplished following a reported method [24] with some modifications. The prepared SBA-15 was first dried for 1 h in an oven at 80 °C before being loaded with HPA precursors. Heteropoly acids (HPAs), including HSiW, HPW, and HPMo, were loaded onto SBA-15 using incipient wetness impregnation at 20 wt% loading. 1.25 g of HPA was dissolved in water, while a prescribed amount of 5 g of SBA-15 was slowly added into the solution, and left under stirring at 200 rpm for 3 h. After a 20 h drying at 110 °C, the catalysts were calcined at 400 °C with a ramping rate of 5 °C/min for a duration of 4 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization N2 adsorption-desorption analysis were performed using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 to investigate the surface and pore characteristics of all synthesized catalysts. Before analysis, powder samples were degassed (P < 10−1 Pa) at 200 °C for 4 h to remove any impurities from the catalysts. The BET method and BJH model were used to determine the specific surface area and pore size distribution, respectively. Also, the total pore volume was calculated by measuring nitrogen adsorption at a relative pressure (P/Po) of 0.98. Meanwhile, the small-angle XRD scattering (SAXS) patterns of all synthesized catalysts were obtained by Bruker D8 Discover diffractometer using Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. A small angle scan (1.5 – 5°) data were analysed using DIFFRAC.EVA. software with PDF-2 2013 phase identification. SEM was employed to observe the changes in the surface morphological structure of SBA-15 before and after the incorporation of HPAs and the images were taken using the Quanta FEG 450 SEM. In order to investigate the specific chemical bonds between SBA-15 and catalysts, a FTIR analysis employing a Perkin-Elmer 2000 were performed using the potassium bromide (KBr) pellet technique. NH3-TPD using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with TCD detector was employed to assess the acid properties of the catalysts. In this analysis, 0.05 g of sample was pretreated under He flow for 60 min at 200 °C. The NH3 adsorption was then performed at 120 °C. Desorption of NH3 was conducted from 120 °C to 700 °C with a linear heating rate at 10 °C /min. While, H2-TPR analysis was conducted to examine the redox properties of the SBA-15 support and all prepared catalysts. Similarly, the spectra were measured using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with a TCD detector. In this analysis, 0.05 g of sample were first packed into quartz reactor tube. Prior to desorption, the sample was pretreated at 400 °C for 60 min under He flow. After cooling down to room temperature, the mixture of gases was changed into a final reducing mixture of H2/He with a flow rate of 30 mL/min for another 30 mins. The heating was started up to 1000 °C with a linear heating rate of 10 °C/min. 2.3 Catalytic tests and analysis of products In the glycerol oxydehydration process, 15 g of 85% glycerol was mixed with a catalyst (i.e., 10 wt% SiW/SBA-15 relative to glycerol) in a 100 mL stainless-steel gasket reactor with a magnetic stirring bar. Before the reaction, the reactor was sealed, purged with O2 for 10 mins, and set to 230 °C. Stirring at 300 rpm continued for the 5-hour reaction. The reaction was quenched by cooling in an ice bath. After cooling the reaction sample to room temperature, the sample was collected and centrifuged for 40 min at 4400 rpm to separate the solid catalyst from the liquid mixture. For analysis, 100 μL of the filtered sample was diluted in an aqueous H3PO4 solution with a pH of 2.0 at a dilution factor of 1:100. Quantitative analysis was performed using an Agilent 1260 Infinity HPLC system equipped with a refractive index detector (RID) in series. The HPLC column employed was a ZORBAX Eclipse Plus C18 (4.6 ×100 mm, 3.5 µm). The mobile phase used was 0.001 M H3PO4 aqueous solution at pH 2.0. Concentrations of glycerol and acrylic acid in the product mixture were determined using calibration curves based on standard solutions. Glycerol conversion and product yield were calculated following the procedure reported in [30]. The same procedure was repeated for all synthesized catalysts. 2.4 Catalyst reusability study After the first cycle of reaction, the catalyst was recovered from the reaction mixture by centrifugation and washed with 30 mL of acetone to remove any possible residual organic compounds. Then, the recovered catalyst was washed with deionized water to remove any polar solvent and the washed catalyst was then dried at 110 °C for 20 h. Next, the dried catalyst was calcined for 4 h at 400 °C and the activated catalyst was reused in the same reaction condition and this cycle was repeated for up to two times and products from each cycle were analyzed. The spent catalyst was characterized by means of N2 adsorption-desorption analysis, SEM and EDX analyses. The characteristics of the spent catalyst was then compared with the fresh catalyst in order to observe the changes on the physicochemical and also morphological properties. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The prepared SBA-15 and HPA/SBA-15 catalysts were subjected N2 physisorption analysis, and the obtained results were represented in Table 1. The total surface area and total pore volume of the synthesized SBA-15 were 737 m2/g and 0.6275 cm3/g, respectively. SBA-15 is appropriate for use as a support material for a more efficient and uniform distribution of heteropoly acids owing to its high surface area. Nevertheless, upon introduction of HPA into the SBA-15 support, a decrease in surface area was seen, with values ranging between 421 and 498 m2/g. Meanwhile, the pore volume showed only a slight decrease in pore with values ranging between 0.4435 and 0.5258 cm3/g was observed. This phenomenon was due to the deposition of Keggin units inside the meso-channels and was homogenously dispersed on the surface of SBA-15 support’s hexagonally ordered mesoporous [28,31]. Moreover, all three catalysts had average pore sizes that are closely comparable to that of the SBA-15 support, within the range of 52–54 Å. This demonstrates that all supported catalysts maintained mesoporous structures after HPA incorporation. Fig. 1 displays the N2 physisorption isotherms and the pore size distribution profiles of the prepared SBA-15 and HPA/SBA-15 catalysts. The figure demonstrates that all isotherms exhibit a type IV model, indicating the characteristic traits of uniform cylindrical-shaped channels a narrow distribution of pore sizes in mesoporous materials [32]. The findings further showed that, even after the incorporation of HPA, every developed catalyst successfully maintained the SBA-15 supports’ mesoporous channels. Furthermore, at almost the same relative pressure (P/P0 values between 0.45 and 1), all isotherms exhibit a H1 hysteresis loop, indicating the characteristic occurrence of capillary condensation within uniformly distributed pores [33]. Meanwhile, Fig. 1(b) shows the BJH pore size distribution profiles of the prepared SBA-15 and HPA/SBA-15 catalysts. The depicted figure reveals that the entirety of the samples exhibited a narrow distribution of pore sizes between 50 Å and 100 Å. Also, the step’s sharpness suggested that the mesopore size distribution was uniform [25]. Remarkably, mesopore diameter values that were nearly identical to one another, around 76.4 Å, were exhibited by all the HPA/SBA-15 catalysts, by which these values corresponded to the maximum of the pore size distribution profiles. The results were also slightly higher than those for SBA-15 (75.5 Å). In conclusion, these results demonstrated that all HPA/SBA-15 catalysts were successfully synthesized. The formation of a hexagonal mesoporous structure was determined based on the characteristics of diffraction peaks. Fig. 2 shows the SAXS patterns within the 2Ɵ of (a) 0.6–5° and (b) 1.3–3° for the prepared SBA-15 and HPA/SBA-15 catalysts. From the SAXS patterns displayed in Fig. 2(a), the SBA-15 exhibits one characteristic peak at 0.89° (100) and two well-resolved humps at around 1.53° (110) and 1.81° (200) which are attributed to the 2D hexagonal p6mm mesostructures [25]. The (100) peak is attributed to the regular interwall spacing of the mesoporous channels. Meanwhile, the (110) and (200) humps indicate the presence of ordered channels in SBA-15 mesostructures. The intensity of (110) and (200) phase humps decreased after HPA impregnation, indicating partial disruption of SBA-15 support. The finding is in agreement with the physisorption analysis findings presented in Table 1 as compared to the SBA-15 support, both external surface area and total pore volume underwent an observable decrease. Despite these results, all catalysts sufficiently maintained SBA-15′s mesopore structure. The specific changes in the SBA-15 support’ morphological structure upon impregnation of different HPA are observed based on SEM micrographs. The SEM images of the prepared SBA-15, and HPA/SBA-15 catalysts at 10,000X magnification are presented in Fig. 3. In Fig. 3(a), the SBA-15 support could be observed to be composed of rope-like domains (elongated meso-channels) of roughly 0.5 µm in size and a fibrous structure morphology [29,34]. Based on this finding, mesoporous SBA-15 was concluded to be successfully synthesized. Moreover, the long-fibre-like mesoporous channel structure was retained even after HPA incorporation for all catalysts as depicted in Fig. 3(b, c and d). This result indicates the successful formation of a mesoporous channel within the catalyst system. However, the formation of crystal of HPW, HSiW and HPMo Fig. 3(b, c and d) could be observed attached to the external surface of the catalysts as indicated in their respective figures. This observation suggests that some HPA crystals were not deposited in SBA-15 support’s internal mesopores during catalyst impregnation which also corresponds to the decrease in the catalyst’s total surface area as shown by the N2 adsorption-desorption results in Table 1. Interestingly, PMo/SBA-15 catalyst showed the most PMo crystals being deposited on the external surface compared to the other catalysts. Fourier transformed infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was employed to confirm the interaction between heteropoly acids (HPAs) on the surface of SBA-15. Fig. 4 presents the FTIR spectra for the prepared SBA-15 and HPA/SBA-15 catalysts in a wavenumber range of 4000 – 400 cm−1. As shown in the figure, the broad Si-O-Si asymmetric stretching band, which is the typical characteristics band of SBA-15, was found at 1220–1064 cm−1. Besides, SBA-15 support also exhibited two distinct bands at 800 cm−1 and 462 cm−1, corresponding to the Si-O-Si symmetric stretching band and the bending vibrational mode of Si-O-Si, respectively [29]. Interestingly, the vibration bands at 462, 800, and 1080 cm−1 are found consistently in all synthesized catalysts. This suggests that even after HPA incorporation, the prepared SBA-15 support maintained the ability to retain the desirable silica framework. Meanwhile, in each sample, a broad absorption band centered on 3446 cm−1 is seen. This may be due to Si-OH surface absorption, which results in hydrogen bond formation [35]. Moreover, the presence of adsorbed water molecules is detected at 1638 cm−1. This band corresponds to the bending vibrational mode of O-H bonds in OH groups [36]. Furthermore, the PW/SBA-15 catalyst’s FTIR spectra (Fig. 4(b)) clearly reveal the IR bands of respective HPW Keggin ions. These bands are observed at 1082 cm−1, which can be attributed to the asymmetry vibrational mode of P-Oa, 964 cm−1, indicating W-Od; terminally bonded oxygen to W atom, and 804 cm−1 signifying W-Oc-W; corner-sharing oxygen connecting W13O13 units [37]. Likewise, the SiW/SBA-15 catalyst’s spectra show characteristic bands at 1057 cm−1, which is attributable to the asymmetry vibrational mode of Si-Oa, 947 cm−1, indicating W-Od; terminally bonded oxygen to W atom, 799 cm−1 signifying W-Oc-W; corner-sharing oxygen connecting W13O13 units [38] and PMo/SBA-15 catalyst shows the respective IR bands at 1078 cm−1, 959 cm−1, 800 cm−1 [39]. Overall, the observed bands in all prepared catalysts reveal that during sample preparation for all catalysts, the Keggin unit structure was maintained successfully. NH3-TPD analysis was employed to examine the surface acidity of the prepared SBA-15, PW/SBA-15, SiW/SBA-15, and PMo/SBA-15 catalysts with the corresponding profiles depicted in Fig. 5(i). In general, acid sites can be categorized based on their strength, including weak- (150–300 °C), medium- (300–500 °C) and strong- (500–650 °C) acidity levels [40]. As depicted in Fig. 5(i), the PW/SBA-15 catalyst showed a broad peak at 124 °C and a small hump at 530 °C. This indicates that both weak and strong acid sites are present. On the SiW/SBA-15 catalyst, a peak assigned to weak- and a hump assigned to medium- strength acid sites were observed at 101 °C and 394 °C, respectively. For PMo/SBA-15 catalyst, the weak strength peak was recorded at 93 °C and a hump at 382 °C, indicating medium strength acid sites. In comparison to the bulk heteropoly acid reported by Thanasilp et al. [24], all synthesized catalysts exhibited a peak and a hump that shifted towards lower temperatures, accompanied by intensity reduction. These observations suggest a weakening in acid sites’ strength, potentially attributed to interactions with SBA-15 support. Moreover, Table 2 gives the amount of ammonia consumed during TPD measurement. The overall acidity of the HPA/SBA-15 catalysts, was in the following order: PW/SBA-15 > SiW/SBA-15 > PMo/SBA-15, which aligns well with an earlier study [28]. It is imperative to highlight that the introduction of heteropoly acids did not simply result in a rise in the total acid sites on the support surface. Instead, the existing acid sites were substituted for other acidic sites [40]. After heteropoly acid impregnation, the overall acidity of the SBA-15 support surface was increased. As a result of the weak interaction between the SBA-15 support and HPA, the Bronsted acid properties of the molecule were maintained and the proportion of low, medium, and strong acid sites was increased. In contrast, it is observed that a fraction of HPA exhibits a reduction in acidity as a consequence of a disruption of the Keggin structure. The redox properties of the prepared SBA-15, PW/SBA-15, SiW/SBA-15, and PMo/SBA-15 catalysts was determined by H2-TPR analysis and Fig. 5(ii) shows the H2-TPR profiles. As shown in Fig. 5(ii), SBA-15 support does not show any reduction peak since it is irreducible. In contrast, the H2-TPR profile of all synthesized catalysts showed three characteristic peaks corresponding to sequential reduction of Keggin ions. PW/SBA-15 catalyst demonstrated three reduction peaks at 461, 619 and 751 °C, corresponding to the decomposition of Keggin ions of HPW to bronze structure (HxWO3), reduction of WO3 to WO3−x sub-oxides at higher temperature, and interaction between dispersed HPW species with SBA-15 support, respectively [41]. Meanwhile, the SiW/SBA-15 catalyst also displayed three reduction peaks at 454, 647 and 815 °C, which correspond to the reduction of Keggin ions of HSiW, reduction of WO3 to WO3−x sub-oxides, and interaction peak of HSiW and SBA-15 support, respectively [42]. It was found that both catalysts recorded a reduction peak that was in line with the reduction peaks of bulk WO3 [43]. For PMo/SBA-15 catalysts, three reduction peaks were recorded at 470, 628 and 870 °C. The first peak was attributed to the decomposition of HPMo keggin ions, followed by the reduction of MoO3 to MoO3−x. At the highest temperature peak represented the interaction peak of HPMo and SBA-15 support [44]. As summarized in Table 2, the Keggin-structured of HPAs/SBA-15 possessed appropriate redox properties which oxidation potential decreased in the following order: PMo/SBA-15 > PW/SBA-15 > SiW/SBA-15. These findings are in line with previous work reported by Kozhevnikov [45]. It should be noted that the amount of hydrogen consumed by the SiW/SBA-15 catalyst was slightly low. In Fig. 4(ii), the reduction peaks of SiW/SBA-15 catalyst slightly shifted to higher temperatures, indicating the existence of a strong interaction between SiW and SBA-15, which might have led to the decrease in the amount of consumed hydrogen [44]. Meanwhile, a high amount of consumed hydrogen was seen on PMo/SBA-15 catalyst, which might be due to the fact that molybdenum could be partially reduced at high temperatures [46]. 3.2 Influence of different HPAs on catalytic performance The performance of HPAs/SBA-15 catalysts was subsequently investigated for glycerol oxydehydration reaction. The catalytic test was conducted at 230 °C by using 15 g of 85% stock glycerol as reactant and a catalyst loading of 10 wt% in a 5 h reaction. Fig. 6 presents the results of activity for different catalysts in glycerol oxydehydration. In, actuality, SBA-15 support was also tested under the same reaction conditions. In the absence of heteropoly acid, the results demonstrated 34% glycerol conversion with no corresponding yield of acrylic acid after 5 h of reaction. The occurrence of glycerol conversion can likely be ascribed to the acid sites present on the SBA-15 surface, particularly in combination with high reaction temperatures. This synergy facilitates glycerol dehydration, leading to other substances formation. In spite of this, no acrylic acid was detected because the SBA-15 surface lacked the necessary redox amount to catalyze the acrolein (product of glycerol dehydration) into acrylic acid. Meanwhile, it was observed that the utilization of HPA-supported SBA-15 catalysts resulted in a higher degree of glycerol conversion compared to the utilization of SBA-15 alone, across all types of catalysts. This was because HPA/SBA-15 catalysts had more capability to dehydrate glycerol than SBA-15 support owing to their higher acid strengths as recorded in Table 2. Fig. 6 highlights the superior glycerol conversion of the PW/SBA-15 catalyst compared to the other two HPA/SBA-15 catalysts. Over the observed reaction time, PW/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited a notable increase in glycerol conversion, rising from 67.1% at 1 h of reaction to an 85% glycerol conversion at a reaction time of 5 h. Similarly, SiW/SBA-15 catalyst also displayed an upward trend in glycerol conversion, from 65% at 1 h, to 79.3% at 3 h, and further to 84.2% at 5 h. However, PMo/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited comparatively lower glycerol conversions across all observed reaction times, reaching only 61.3% glycerol conversion after 5 h. The PW/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited notably stronger acid strength compared to other catalysts, thereby resulting in the highest glycerol conversion. Moreover, HPW was more stable at high reaction temperatures in aqueous media [47]. This increases the likelihood of providing strong acid protons for the dehydration of glycerol. When compared with the other catalysts used, the PMo/SBA-15 catalyst demonstrated the lowest glycerol conversion because of its lower thermal stability and acid strength in comparison to the other synthesized catalysts [48]. It is noteworthy that all three catalysts could successfully catalyze single-step glycerol-to-acrylic acid oxydehydration reaction. The yield of acrylic acid using a PW/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited a progressive increase, from 10.6% at 1 h, 13.7% at 3 h, and reaching 15.9% at 5 h, accompanied by acrylic acid selectivities ranging from 15.8% to 18.7%. Interestingly, SiW/SBA-15 catalyst also showed similar increasing trend in acrylic acid yield and selectivity over time with the highest selectivity recorded was 18.3% at 5 h of reaction. However, PMo/SBA-15 catalyst demonstrated comparatively lower selectivity for acrylic acid yielding only 9.1% of acrylic acid after a reaction time of 5 h. In short, the selectivities for acrylic acid using HPA-supported SBA-15 catalysts increased in the order of PMo/SBA-15 < SiW/SBA-15 < PW/SBA-15, which was consistent with their acid strength and redox properties. The reason why PMo/SBA-15 catalyst had low catalytic activity can be explained by the fact that this catalyst had higher oxidative ability which might accelerate glycerol oxydehydration to other undesired by-products. As mentioned previously, an appropriate amount of redox properties was required to partially oxidize acrolein to acrylic acid since highly active species would result in a more complete oxidation reaction [49]. Based on the results, it was indicated that successful glycerol oxydehydration required a bi-functional catalyst with strong acid sites and mild oxidative capabilities. Besides, the combined role of acid properties and mild oxidative capabilities, together with the well-defined, and ordered mesopores of SBA-15 support enhanced the catalyst’s activity and selectivity. The mesoporous SBA-15 support, provided high surface areas and allow efficient diffusion of glycerol and the intermediates, contributing to shape the selectivity for acrylic acid. Since PW/SBA-15 catalyst achieved the highest catalytic performance, it was chosen for further exploration. The performance of PW/SBA-15 catalysts with various acid loadings in a 5 h reaction at 230 °C by using 15 g of 85% glycerol as reactant and a catalyst loading of 10 wt%. Fig. 7 presents the results and comparison of activity for PW/SBA-15 catalyst at varying acid loadings in glycerol oxydehydration reaction. Fig. 7 shows that increasing the HPW loading from 10 to 30 wt% resulted in a significant increase in glycerol conversion, rising from 29.7% to 87.8%. The well-dispersed HPW on SBA-15 improved glycerol molecules’ accessibility to the catalytically active protons present on the supported catalyst, thereby increasing the glycerol conversion [40]. However, the 40PW/SBA-15 catalyst showed the highest glycerol conversion (94.1%) although it had lower total acidity than the 20PW/SBA-15 and 30PW/SBA-15 catalysts. This phenomenon may be attributed to the presence of more active material on the SBA-15 catalyst’s surface rather than within its mesopores. This abundance of active material on the surface could lead to side reactions, which contributed to higher glycerol conversion. It is noteworthy that all four catalysts successfully catalyze single-step glycerol oxydehydration to acrylic acid. The selectivities for acrylic acid using PW/SBA-15 catalyst at various acid loadings were in an order of 30PW/SBA-15 (19.9%) > 20PW/SBA-15 (18.7%) > 40PW/SBA-15 (11.7%) > 10PW/SBA-15 (2.4%), which was consistent with their acid strength. In theory, enhancing a catalyst’s acidity should result in higher catalytic activity [50]. Given the low loading of HPW anions, it is reasonable to expect that the 10PW/SBA-15 catalyst would exhibit lower reactivity compared to other solid catalysts. This could be ascribed to the limited availability of active sites resulting from the low amount of HPW loaded onto the catalyst. Meanwhile, despite higher HPW anion loadings, 40PW/SBA-15 catalyst demonstrated reduced activity compared with 20PW/SBA-15 and 30PW/SBA-15 catalysts. The findings suggest that HPW loadings exceed 30 wt%, the mesopores may have experienced significant blockages. Consequently, the acid sites within these mesopores may have been inaccessible during the reaction [51]. In short, glycerol oxydehydration requires a sufficient amount of acid sites with better distribution to enhance catalytic performance and better selectivity for acrylic acid. The best HPW loading was 30 wt%, ensuring an even distribution of acid sites and redox properties in the mesoporous SBA-15 support. The catalyst denoted as 30PW/SBA-15 exhibited superior catalytic performance, characterized by the attainment of the maximum glycerol conversion and acrylic acid yield. Previous studies in liquid phase glycerol oxydehydration reaction using SiW/Al2O3 and V6-SiW/HZSM-5 catalysts reported glycerol conversions ranging from 84% to 99.67% with acrylic acid yields, reaching 25–36.23% [23,24]. However, it is worth highlighting that this work employed a significantly higher initial glycerol concentration (85 wt%) exceeding by more than fourfold the concentrations utilized in prior researches (20 wt%). Furthermore, it is essential to highlight that the reaction in this study was done in the absence of any external oxidizing agent (i.e., H2O2). Hence, it could be concluded that the actual amount of glycerol being converted and acrylic acid yielded in this study surpasses those reported earlier. 3.3 Reusability of the catalyst In the present study, a series of three consecutive cycles were carried out to investigate the reusability of the PW/SBA-15 catalyst in glycerol oxydehydration to acrylic acid. The catalyst showed significant losses of activity with every catalytic run. The conversion of glycerol using a fresh catalyst decreased to 29.7% after three consecutive runs. Acrylic acid yield also exhibited similar patterns, declining to 0% after the third catalytic run. The results indicated that this catalyst had low stability since there was a remarkable drop glycerol conversion and acrylic acid yield compared to the fresh catalyst. Moreover, the loss of activity with every catalytic run could be explained by the catalyst being severely deactivated. In order to investigate the catalyst deactivation mechanism, SEM characterization was performed on both fresh and spent catalysts, and the resulting images are presented in Fig. 8. From the SEM images, it can be confirmed that the catalyst structures underwent changes with each run. Fig. 8(b) shows that the typical SBA-15 morphology (extended rod-like) was no longer retained after the first recovery which contributed to the loss of catalytic performance. After the second regeneration (R2 catalyst), it became evident that the catalyst morphology had suffered noticeable deterioration. Fig. 8(c) shows coke deposition and particle agglomeration on the catalyst surface. Following the catalytic experiments using R1 catalysts, glycerol polymerization occurred on the catalyst surfaces, resulting in the formation of coke, which exhibited a distinct black appearance [18]. Another research group also reported similar observations using H3PW12O40/MCM-41 catalysts in a glycerol dehydration reaction [52]. The elemental composition of C, O, Si, P and W for the fresh and spent catalysts is shown in Table 3. The EDX analysis successfully detected specific elements, including Si, O, P, and W, on the external surface of the fresh catalyst. In addition, R1 and R2 catalysts contain C element, which was attributed to coke formation during reaction [53]. As for P and W elements, a significant reduction was observed for spent catalysts compared to fresh catalyst. This finding could be attributed to the leaching of HPW Keggin units from the catalyst. This observation was in agreement with the published literature [50] in which HPA tends to leach out when an aqueous phase is present. Table 4 shows the textural properties of the fresh catalyst and spent catalysts. After three consecutive runs, the N2 adsorption-desorption analysis revealed substantial reductions in the catalyst’s total surface area and total pore volume, decreasing from 447 to 188 m2/g and 0.4435–0.1674 cm3/g respectively. The lower surface area of the spent catalyst might be caused by pore blockage due to carbon deposition on the surface of the catalyst after reaction. The decreasing trend of surface area and pore volume is in agreement with the result obtained by [52]. Meanwhile, the average pore diameter significantly increased from 54.89 to 77.57 Å after three consecutive runs. Due to repeated use, drying and calcination after each cycle, the spent catalyst may have undergone complete pore collapse after three reaction cycles. 4 Conclusion Different heteropoly acid-based catalysts supported on mesoporous SBA-15 were successfully synthesized via the incipient-wetness post-impregnation method with varying types of acids (HPW, HSiW, and HPMo). These catalysts were utilized for the oxydehydration of glycerol. Furthermore, a detailed analysis of the surface morphology and chemical bond characteristics confirmed that all the catalysts effectively maintained the mesoporous structure and chemical bonding inherent to the typical SBA-15 support. Among the various catalysts studied, PW/SBA-15 demonstrated remarkable performance, achieving a high glycerol conversion of 87.8% with the highest acrylic acid yield of 17.5% when operated at 230 °C for 5 h. This exceptional performance can be attributed to the catalyst's strong acid sites and its mild oxidative capability. coredata.dc:description: Heteropoly acids (HPAs) of the Keggin type exhibit substantial Brønsted acidity and are commonly utilized as acid catalysts, particularly in acrylic acid synthesis via glycerol oxydehydration. The primary goal of this research is to comprehensively assess the morphological and physicochemical properties of SBA-15 supported HPAs (H4SiW12O40.xH2O, H3PW12O40.xH2O, and H3PMo12O40.xH2O). The synthesized catalysts were characterized via physisorption analysis, XRD, SEM, FT-IR, NH3-TPD, and H2-TPR. Furthermore, the catalyst's catalytic activity in acrylic acid synthesis via single-step liquid phase glycerol oxydehydration was evaluated by correlating its characteristics with glycerol conversion and acrylic acid yields. The PW/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited the best performance, with the highest acrylic acid yield reaching 17.5% at 87.8% glycerol conversion. Given that the partial oxidation of acrolein to acrylic acid necessitates an optimal level of redox properties, the superior performance of PW/SBA-15 was characterized by high acid sites and moderate oxidative capabilities.
coredata.dc:title: One-pot synthesis of acrylic acid from glycerol over SBA-15 supported heteropoly acid catalysts: Influence of mesoporosity and acidity
